comments.body: Remove this note please. The prerequisites at the top require a Load Balancer. This is not related to hostpath.

@jeffmendoza I will address your comments in the next push, thanks. I tried several ways to get an external IP visible but never saw an external IP for the wordpress service. Can you suggest a page to read or what needs to be done to get an external ip for wp? From my reading it appeared that `LoadBalancer` was tied to cloud providers.

The docs are [here](http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/services/#type-loadbalancer). Yes, `LoadBalancer` and volume support are both dependent on the environment external to kubernetes, however they are orthogonal. 

See the last bullet [here](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/examples/guidelines.md#up-front). We would rather have the example assume a particular capability and then provide links to documentation to do it another way (Node port), rather than have every example attempt to support every environment. Examples get really hard to follow when there are so many if/then's in the flow.

@jeffmendoza Thanks for the links. I've pushed my latest changes. I am still not able to get an external ip in my test env but I don't think that matters for the changes I'm submitting. Please allow a merge if this LGTY.  Thanks!

comments.body:
Even though it should be obvious what each line does from the yaml file name, the url is so long that I need to scroll over to see the file name.  I find the length of the url adds a bit of cognitive work.

Consider either creating an environment variable for `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/master/examples/mysql-wordpress-pd` to shorten each command to be more parseable, or add a comment before each line.

Updated to use an env var. Not the Quickstart though. I don't think it makes sense there, as the quickstart is supposed to be the shortest number of commands, something you c&p without caring.

Had to update the tests `cmd/mungedocs/kubectl_dash_f.go` PTAL

The following also works:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/raw/master/examples/mysql-wordpress-pd/wordpress-service.yaml
BTW, did you confirm that `kubectl create -f` works with https?
Maybe we can create a redirector, similar to issues.k8s.io?
code.k8s.io works, but we need a raw.k8s.io
?raw=true doesn't survive redirect, sadly. May be fixable

comments.body: k8s v1.2 adds support dynamic provisioning support (https://docs.openshift.org/latest/install_config/persistent_storage/dynamically_provisioning_pvs.html#dynamic-pvs-requesting-storage), so that volumes don't need to be manually provisioned ahead of time--but it's still experimental. After v1.3 is launched, we should update this example to use dynamic provisioning.
Sounds good.

comments.body: How can the user easily test that their cluster meets each of these requirements?
The version is easy with `kubectl version`. For the others, examples should link out to relevant documentation.

Link to 1.2? And/or a document that explains how to check?

http://releases.k8s.io
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/user-guide/kubectl/kubectl_version.md

Rereading this, I think this is pretty confusing and we need to make this section much simpler and assume less of the user.  The links don't clearly state how to check if these are enabled for a given cluster.  The _Persistent Volume Claims_ links to a document self described as `This document describes the current state of PersistentVolumes in Kubernetes. Familiarity with volumes is suggested.`  Reading and understanding the PV doc shouldn't be required for me to do the example. 

This should probably be integrated into setting up the cluster.
